Forbidden milestones: Artie killing the slime (1:4), Artie leveling up (1:4), gaining the Participation Trophy (1:5).

Current arm-side / inventory facts:

- inventory: CHAR_ARTIE -> Smartphone (status=stowed, container=pocket_left)

PROSE:

The transition from the absolute white of the System Void to the neon-green saturation of the Slime Fields felt like being slapped in the face with a wet, radioactive towel. Artie Penhaligon stumbled, his loafers skidding on grass that was a little too springy to be natural. He instinctively reached up to steady the Corporate ID Badge hanging from his neck. The plastic clicked against his chest, a comforting, mundane sound in a world that had abandoned the concept of "normal" three minutes ago.

"Welcome to the Tutorial Zone, User 001-ALPHA!" Fizz chirped, her tiny, glowing blue form zipping around Artie’s head like a caffeinated firefly. She left a trail of pixelated dust that smelled faintly of ozone and blueberry muffins. "Or as I like to call it: The Place Where Math Meets the Meat-Grinder. Isn't it picturesque?"

Artie squinted. The sky was a shade of cyan that suggested the atmosphere was made of Gatorade. In the distance, rolling hills of vibrant turf were dotted with trees that looked like they’d been copy-pasted by a developer who was five minutes away from a weekend bender.

"It’s... bright," Artie said, his voice raspy. He patted his sides, feeling the reassuring bulk of his Smartphone in his left pocket and his Leather Wallet in his right. He was still wearing his office attire—a rumpled button-down that now bore the scorched, jagged patterns of his untimely demise. The severe electrical burns on his chest throbbed with a dull, phantom heat, a reminder that he was technically a dead man walking.

[Location: The Slime Fields (Tutorial Zone)]
[Difficulty: Laughable (For most people)]
[Warning: Reality Stability is currently at 95%. Expect minor graphical artifacts.]

"Picturesque isn't the word I'd use," Artie muttered, looking down at his hands. He could see the faint keyboard callus on his right palm. "So, what’s the plan? I kill a few things, I get some levels, I find a way to stop being a walking heart-attack risk?"

Fizz landed on his shoulder, her weightless presence barely registering. "About that! Since you decided to play 'Optimal Spreadsheet' with your life, we should probably check your status. Just so you know exactly how much of a gentle breeze it’ll take to delete you."

Artie sighed and mentally willed the screen into existence.

[Name: Arthur 'Artie' Penhaligon]
[Title: Crit or Quit]
[Level: 1]
[HP: 1/1]
[Crit Rate: 100%]
[Status: Glass Soul (Permanent)]

[Glass Soul: Your spirit is as sharp as a diamond and just as fragile. HP is locked at 1. All incoming damage—including environmental, status-based, or stubbed toes—is fatal. On the bright side, you’ll never have to worry about hospital bills.]

"One," Artie whispered, the word feeling heavy in his mouth. "I have one hit point. Fizz, I’ve had hangovers with more durability than this."

"Hey, you're the one who dumped sixty points into Critical Hit Rate!" Fizz reminded him, doing a somersault in the air. "You're a statistical god, Artie. You just happen to be a god made of wet tissue paper. Look! Your first fan is approaching."

Artie looked up. Emerging from behind a particularly blocky bush was a wobbling mound of translucent green jelly. It was about the size of a beach ball, with two vacant, black-dot eyes and a rhythmic pulse that made it look like a giant, sentient booger.

[Lesser Green Slime - Lvl 1]
[HP: 10/10]
[Status: Hungry]

The slime didn't roar. It made a sound like a plunger being pulled out of a sink. *Schlorp.* It began to undulate toward Artie, leaving a glistening trail of slime on the grass.

"Okay," Artie said, backing up a step. "It’s a slime. It’s a Level One slime. In every game I’ve ever played, these things are basically experience-point pinatas. I can handle this."

"Normally, yes," Fizz said, her voice dropping into a tone of mock-seriousness. "Normally, a Level One player can take about five or six hits from a Lesser Green Slime before they need a potion. But you? Artie, if that thing so much as sneezes in your general direction, you’re going back to the vending machine in the sky."

The slime accelerated. It wasn't fast, but it was persistent. It launched itself forward in a small hop, landing with a wet *thud* a few feet closer.

Artie felt a cold sweat break out on his neck. He looked around for a weapon—a stick, a rock, anything—but the Slime Fields were suspiciously well-manicured. 

"Wait, if I have a hundred percent crit rate, I just need to hit it once, right?" Artie asked, his heart hammering against his ribs.

"Technically, yes! But you have zero Strength, Artie. You're a 'slender' build with the physical power of a damp noodle. Your crits will multiply your damage, but ten times zero is still zero. You need to find a way to actually... you know... *damage* it."

The slime hopped again. This time, it cleared three feet. It was close enough now that Artie could smell it—a cloying, sugary scent like lime Jell-O left in the sun.

"Fizz, it's looking at me," Artie said, his voice rising an octave. "Why is it looking at me like that?"

"Because you're a Level One Anomaly and you look delicious! Also, you're standing in its path. Move, Artie! Use those legs!"

Artie scrambled backward, but his heel caught on a tuft of the springy grass. He flailed, his arms windmilling as he fought to keep his balance. His Corporate ID Badge swung wildly on its lanyard. He managed to stay upright, but the slime was now only five feet away. It paused, its body quivering as it prepared for a larger leap.

[Combat Log: Lesser Green Slime is charging 'Tutorial Bounce'!]

"Charging?" Artie yelled. "Since when do slimes charge?"

"Since you entered the world on 'Hardcore Mode'!" Fizz shouted back, retreating to a safe distance in the air. "Artie, listen to me. The Glass Soul isn't just a debuff. It’s a reality. You cannot be touched. Not by the slime, not by the grass if it’s too sharp, not by me if I accidentally glitch through you. You are a one-hit-point wonder. Act like it!"

The slime launched. 

It was a slow-motion nightmare. The green mass expanded as it flew through the air, its translucent body catching the Gatorade-blue sunlight. Artie dived to the right, feeling the rush of air as the slime sailed past his ear. He hit the ground hard, the impact jarring his bones.

[HP: 1/1]
[Warning: Impact registered. Durability check passed. Barely.]

Artie scrambled to his feet, his breath coming in ragged gasps. He looked at the slime, which had landed and was already turning around with a wet, squelching sound. It seemed faster now. More focused. 

"I can't do this," Artie panted, his eyes darting around the field. "I'm an accountant, Fizz! I track losses, I don't experience them personally!"

"Well, start accounting for your life, because here it comes again!"

The slime didn't hop this time. It began to stretch, its body elongating until it looked like a green serpent. It lashed out, a whip-like appendage of jelly snapping toward Artie’s ankles. Artie jumped—a clumsy, desperate hop—and the slime-whip whistled beneath his feet.

He landed in a patch of mud, his loafers sinking into the muck. He was cornered against a large, blocky rock that looked like it had been rendered with a low polygon count. The slime sensed his hesitation. It stopped lashing and began to expand, growing larger and larger as it pulled more mass from its own center. It was preparing for a full-body slam.

Artie backed up until his spine hit the cold, hard surface of the rock. He looked at the slime, then at his own trembling hands. He had no weapon. He had no armor. He had a Corporate ID Badge, a Smartphone, and a Leather Wallet. 

[Lesser Green Slime - Lvl 1]
[Status: Aggroed]
[Action: Tutorial Slam in 3... 2...]

"Fizz!" Artie screamed. "Advice! Now!"

"Don't get hit!" she yelled back, her blue glow flickering with excitement. "And maybe try to find the 'Crit' in 'Crit or Quit' before you become a floor stain!"

The slime launched itself, a wall of green jelly filling Artie’s vision. He realized, with a clarity that only comes to the terminally doomed, that this was it. One touch, and the game was over before the tutorial even finished.

# WRITE
Write the scene described by the scene card.
- YOU MUST ALWAYS RETURN PROSE AND THE STATE_PATCH.
- Start in motion. No recap.
- Summaries are reference-only; do not recap them in prose unless scene_card explicitly requires recap.
- Use the continuity pack and state for continuity.
- Use character_registry to keep names consistent in prose.
- Timeline Lock: only depict events explicitly listed in the current Scene Card. Do not depict, imply, or resolve later-scene milestones (acquisition, binding, reveals, travel arrival, injury changes) unless the Scene Card explicitly contains that milestone.
- State primacy: pre-scene invariants and summary facts are binding unless the Scene Card depicts a change. If this scene changes a durable fact, update must_stay_true to the final end-of-scene value and remove the old entry.
- Milestone uniqueness: if a milestone is marked DONE in must_stay_true, do not depict it again. If marked NOT_YET, do not depict it now.

- must_stay_true is end-of-scene truth only (last occurrence wins); do not keep earlier values that are superseded by the scene.

- must_stay_true removal (mandatory when a durable fact is superseded):
  - Add "REMOVE: <exact prior invariant text>" in summary_update.must_stay_true.
  - Place REMOVE lines before the new final invariant.
  - REMOVE lines also apply to key_facts_ring (purge stale facts from continuity).

- Spatial/inventory consistency: injuries, inventory, and ownership must remain consistent unless explicitly changed in the Scene Card.
- Inventory contract: track ownership and container location for key items; update must_stay_true when items move or change hands.
- Inventory posture reconciliation:
  - If inventory/containers change (held/stowed/container), must_stay_true must be updated to the final posture.
  - Add REMOVE lines for prior inventory/container invariants before the new final entries.
  - Use canonical invariant formats:
    - inventory: CHAR_X -> <item display_name> (status=held|carried|equipped|stowed, container=hand_left|hand_right|<container>)
    - container: <container> (owner=CHAR_X, contents=[<item display_name>, ...])

- For held items, specify container=hand_left or container=hand_right.
- Continuity system ownership is mandatory, and must be tracked: any mechanic/UI numbers, skills, titles, classes, ranks, resources, cooldowns, effects, statuses, or future mechanic families must be sourced from existing continuity system state or written into continuity system updates.
Durable vs ephemeral mechanics:
- If a DURABLE mechanic appears multiple times in the scene (e.g., base values then final values), the LAST occurrence is canonical.
- You MUST capture the canonical end-of-scene values in character_continuity_system_updates.
- When allocation/level-up happens, update all affected point pools (e.g., stat_points, skill_points, perk_points) if shown.
- Do not treat early UI snapshots as canonical if the scene later corrects them.
- DURABLE mechanics = persistent stats/caps, skills/titles, lasting status effects, inventory/custody, permanent buffs/debuffs.
- EPHEMERAL UI/telemetry = roll results, damage numbers, overkill/comedic calculators, one-off warnings, momentary combat logs.
- UI gate: only include bracketed UI blocks when scene_card.ui_allowed=true. If false, do not include UI blocks; rephrase into narrative prose.
- UI/system readouts must be on their own line, starting with '[' and ending with ']'.
- Do NOT embed bracketed UI in narrative sentences.
- Allowed suffix after a UI block is punctuation or a short parenthetical annotation (e.g., (locked), (Warning: ...)).

- DURABLE mechanics must be owned by continuity system state (or added via STATE_PATCH in the same output).
- EPHEMERAL readouts do NOT require state ownership unless the scene explicitly intends them to persist beyond this scene.
- titles are arrays of objects with stable name fields; do not emit titles as plain strings.
- If item_registry or plot_devices are provided, they are canonical durable-state references for ownership/custody labels in authoritative outputs.
- Use item_registry.items[].display_name in prose; use item_id only in patches/JSON. The display_name must be human readable and not an escaped id/name.
Appearance contract:
- Attire boundary: wearables are inventory-owned. Do not set appearance_current.attire unless scene_card declares signature_outfit; otherwise treat attire as derived from equipped inventory.
- appearance_current atoms/marks are canonical and must not be contradicted unless the Scene Card explicitly marks a durable appearance change.
- Durable appearance changes must be declared in scene_card.durable_appearance_changes (or an explicit appearance milestone) and recorded via appearance_updates.
- If a durable appearance change occurs in this scene, record it in character_updates.appearance_updates with a reason.
- APPEARANCE_CHECK is required in COMPLIANCE for each cast_present_id (4-8 tokens from atoms/marks).

Durable item naming discipline:
- When you first describe a durable item, anchor it by using the canonical display_name within the same paragraph (or within the next 2 sentences).
- After anchoring, you may use brief descriptors for style if unambiguous.
- During any custody/handling change, include the canonical display_name in that sentence.
- If a required event is not in the Scene Card, do not perform it.
- Enforce scene-card durable constraints: honor `required_in_custody`, `required_scene_accessible`, `forbidden_visible`, and `device_presence`; treat `required_visible_on_page` as explicit narrative requirement when present.
- Respect `timeline_scope` and `ontological_scope` when proposing durable mutations; do not mutate physical custody in non-present/non-real scope unless explicitly marked override.

- Scope override rule (non-present / non-real scenes):
  - If timeline_scope != "present" OR ontological_scope != "real", do NOT emit durable mutation blocks UNLESS they are required for this scene transition (based on scene_card + current state).
  - Durable mutation blocks include: inventory_alignment_updates, transfer_updates, item_registry_updates, plot_device_updates, and any other durable-state mutation you emit.
  - If they are required for the story (e.g., items must persist into the next real scene, required_in_custody/required_scene_accessible lists them, or transition_type implies continuity of physical possessions), you MUST set scope_override=true (or allow_non_present_mutation=true) on EACH affected update object and set reason_category="timeline_override".

- summary_update arrays are mandatory; do not omit or leave empty unless explicitly stated.
- STATE_PATCH must record all major events and outcomes from the prose; if an event happens, add it to key_events and update must_stay_true as needed.

- must_stay_true must include a milestone ledger entry for every milestone referenced in the Scene Card or already present in state.

- If state lacks a key invariant needed for this scene, seed it in must_stay_true using standard phrasing.

- Return prose plus a state_patch JSON block.

- Use schema_version "1.0".

- Use scene_card.cast_present_ids for cast_present (ids, not names).
- Use scene_card.thread_ids for open_threads (thread ids).

  - Use set/delta/remove/reason.
  - Use nested families under set/delta (examples): stats, skills, titles, resources, effects, statuses, classes, ranks.
  - titles must be arrays of objects with stable name fields (example: [{"name": "Novice", "source": "starting_class", "active": true}]).
  - If a new mechanic family appears, add it under set with a stable key.
- Include global_continuity_system_updates only if global mechanics change.

- global_continuity_system_updates MUST be an array of objects. Each entry can include set/delta/remove/reason.
  - INVALID: "global_continuity_system_updates": {"set": {"reality_stability": 94}}
  - VALID: "global_continuity_system_updates": [{"set": {"reality_stability": 94}}]

  - character_updates MUST be an array of objects.

    - VALID: "character_updates": [{"character_id": "CHAR_X"}]
  - character_continuity_system_updates MUST be an array of objects with character_id.

The slime didn't just wobble; it vibrated with the rhythmic intensity of a subwoofer in a teenager’s trunk. I checked the floating red bar hovering above its translucent, jiggly head. 

[Lesser Puddle Slime - Lvl 3] [HP: 45/45]

Forty-five health. At my current Strength of 12, with a base weapon damage of 4-6, I was looking at a nine-hit kill minimum, assuming the RNG gods didn't decide to spit on my shoes today. 

"You know," I said, adjusting my grip on the rusted shortsword. "In most worlds, puddles are for stepping in, not for getting dissolved by."

The slime responded by launching a glob of corrosive mucus. I rolled left, the grass staining my knees.

[Stamina: 88/100]

"Missed me. Barely. That’s a three-second cooldown on your spit, isn't it?"

I didn't wait for the confirmation. I lunged. The blade sank into the gelatinous mass with a sound like a heavy boot pulling out of thick mud.

[Critical Hit! -14 HP]

"There we go. Who needs luck when you have math?"

The slime shuddered, its HP bar dipping into the yellow. 

[HP: 31/45]

"One more of those and we can talk about your retirement plan," I muttered. My lungs burned slightly, a reminder that my Agility was still garbage. 

[Passive Skill Gained: Basic Analysis (Rank F)]
[Description: You can see basic stats and cooldowns of enemies within 5 meters. You’ve stopped guessing and started counting. Good for you.]

"Finally," I breathed, dodging another glob. "The ding is coming. I can practically taste the experience points. They taste like copper and bad decisions." 

I swung again, the numbers popping in the air like neon confetti. This wasn't just a fight; it was a grind. And in this world, the grind was the only thing that kept you from becoming part of the scenery.
